appeal to authority.name: appeal to authority
appeal to authority.definition: Arguing something is true because an authority figure believes it, without presenting actual evidence.
appeal to authority.example: "It must be true—Dr. Smith said so, and she's a scientist."

appeal to ignorance.name: appeal to ignorance
appeal to ignorance.definition: Claiming something is true because it hasn't been proven false, or vice versa.
appeal to ignorance.example: "No one has proven aliens don’t exist, so they must be real."

appeal to pity.name: appeal to pity
appeal to pity.definition: Attempting to persuade using emotion—specifically sympathy—rather than valid logic.
appeal to pity.example: "You should give me an A—if I fail this class, I’ll lose my scholarship."

appeal to emotion.name: appeal to emotion
appeal to emotion.definition: Manipulating an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.
appeal to emotion.example: "If you care about your children, you’ll support this new policy."

straw man fallacy.name: straw man fallacy
straw man fallacy.definition: Misrepresenting or exaggerating someone’s argument to make it easier to attack.
straw man fallacy.example: "She wants to reduce military spending—clearly, she wants to leave us defenseless."

slippery slope fallacy.name: slippery slope fallacy
slippery slope fallacy.definition: Arguing that one small step will inevitably lead to a chain of related (negative) events.
slippery slope fallacy.example: "If we allow students to redo assignments, soon they’ll expect to retake entire classes."

genetic fallacy.name: genetic fallacy
genetic fallacy.definition: Judging something as good or bad based on its origin rather than its current meaning or context.
genetic fallacy.example: "That idea came from a corrupt politician, so it must be wrong."

false dilemma.name: false dilemma
false dilemma.definition: Presenting only two choices when more options exist.
false dilemma.example: "You’re either with us or against us."

causation fallacy.name: causation fallacy
causation fallacy.definition: Assuming that because two things occur together, one caused the other.
causation fallacy.example: "Since I started wearing these socks, I haven’t lost a game—so they must be lucky."

equivocation.name: equivocation
equivocation.definition: Using ambiguous language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.
equivocation.example: "A feather is light. What is light cannot be dark. So a feather cannot be dark."

hasty generalization.name: hasty generalization
hasty generalization.definition: Drawing a conclusion based on insufficient or non-representative evidence.
hasty generalization.example: "I met two rude New Yorkers, so all New Yorkers must be rude."
